issues.title: Missing Specific Complaint Filing Timeline Requirements
issues.description: California Education Code requires districts to specify that discrimination complaints may be filed within one year of the alleged incident or within one year of when the complainant first obtained knowledge of the facts. While the policy states complaints will be investigated regardless of timeline compliance, it must still inform complainants of the statutory timeline requirements.

legal_citations.text: A complaint alleging discrimination...may be filed by any person, public agency, or organization. The complaint shall be filed within one year from the date the alleged discrimination occurred, or the complainant first obtained knowledge of the facts of the alleged discrimination.

issues.required_language: Complaints alleging unlawful discrimination may be filed within one year from the date the alleged discrimination occurred, or within one year from the date the complainant first obtained knowledge of the facts of the alleged discrimination. However, in cases involving a continuing course of conduct, the complaint shall be filed within one year from the date of the last act of alleged discrimination.

issues.title: Missing Required Annual Board Report on Discrimination Complaints
issues.description: Education Code requires the district to provide an annual summary report to the governing board on the nature and resolution of all discrimination complaints filed during the previous year. This requirement is not addressed in either the policy or regulation.

legal_citations.text: The superintendent or designee shall provide an annual summary report to the governing board on the nature and resolution of all complaints filed with the district pursuant to this section.

issues.required_language: The Superintendent or designee shall provide an annual summary report to the Board on the nature and resolution of all discrimination complaints filed with the district during the previous year, including the number of complaints by category and their resolution.

issues.title: Incomplete Civil Rights Compliance Officer Designation
issues.description: While the regulation identifies a Title IX coordinator, it does not clearly designate compliance officers for other civil rights laws (Section 504/ADA, Government Code 11135). Federal regulations require separate designation of these roles with specific contact information.

legal_citations.text: A recipient that employs fifteen or more persons shall designate at least one person to coordinate its efforts to comply with this part.

issues.required_language: The district also designates the following compliance officers: Section 504/ADA Coordinator: [Name, title, address, phone, email]; Government Code 11135 Coordinator: [Name, title, address, phone, email]. These coordinators are responsible for coordinating compliance efforts and investigating complaints under their respective civil rights laws.

issues.title: Missing Reference to Specific Complaint Forms
issues.description: The regulation references uniform complaint procedures but does not specifically mention that standardized complaint forms are available, as required for accessibility and compliance with procedural requirements.

legal_citations.text: Each local educational agency shall adopt uniform complaint procedures...and shall make available complaint forms.

issues.required_language: Standardized complaint forms are available from the compliance officer, school sites, and the district office, and may also be downloaded from the district website. However, complainants are not required to use the district's complaint form.

issues.title: Missing Specific Reference to Pregnant and Parenting Student Rights
issues.description: While the policy lists pregnancy and parental status as protected characteristics, it does not specifically reference the comprehensive rights of pregnant and parenting students under Education Code Section 222, which requires specific protections and accommodations.

legal_citations.text: A pupil who is pregnant, or who is a parent, shall not be excluded from any educational program, activity, or course offered by the school district solely on the basis of their pregnancy or parental status.

issues.required_language: Pregnant and parenting students have the right to remain in regular classes and participate in extracurricular activities with non-pregnant students throughout their pregnancy, and to return to the same academic and extracurricular program after childbirth. The district shall provide reasonable accommodations to lactating students.
